div.head: THE THEATER OF IAPONIA'S CONSTANCY.
div.p: THE cau≈øe of the en≈øuing ≈øo ≈øtrange and cruell Martyrdomes, ≈øuch as were neuer heard of in the Kingdom of Iaponia, ≈øince the Per≈øecution again≈øt the Chri≈øtians there began, was this as followeth.

Whereas the Emperour of Iaponia ≈øome yeares pa≈øt, had forbidden, by Proclamation throughout all the Prouinces of that Kingdome, vpoÃÑ paine of death, that no Sayler or Mariner ≈øhould bring any Chri≈øtian Religious man into Iaponia; which was a thing very ea≈øy to be done, in regard that Manila the chiefe Citty of the Philippine Ilands is ≈øo neare, and where there is ≈øo great trafficke betweene the Spanyards and Iaponians: Notwith≈øtanding ≈øome there were both Chri≈øtians, and Catholike Marriners, who ≈øtyrred vp with zeale of Gods Honour, not regarding the threats and penaltyes of the lawes, did bring at ≈øundry tymes from Manila into Iaponia, many Religious men, in
≈øecular apparell, to cultiuate and manure that new-planted Vineyard of this new-found Chri≈øtendome.

Among≈øt the ≈øayd Marriners there was one more famous theÃÑ the re≈øt, Captayne of a ≈øhip, called Ioachim, who as he ≈øayled from Manila towards Iaponia, carried with him two very Reuerend Religious men, the one wherof was called Father Pedro de Zuniga of the Order of S. Au≈øten, and the other, Father Lewis de Flores of the Order of S. Dominicke, whome he could not tran≈øport ≈øo ≈øecretly, but they were betrayed by certayne Hollande s, who euen vpoÃÑ the very ≈øhoare of Iaponia, inuaded and robbed Ioachims ≈øhip, and al≈øo accu≈øed him before the Emperours Officers, for bringing the ≈øayd Religious men with him into Iaponia, contrary to the Emperours Proclamation: And for this cau≈øe was Ioachim pre≈øently ca≈øt into pri≈øon at Firandum, togeather with the ≈øayd two Fathers, and all the other Marriners that were Chri≈øtians.

There was at that tyme in the ≈øame Citty re≈øiding another Religious maÃÑ of the order of S. Dominick who went about to deliuer the fore≈øayd Father Lewis out of pri≈øon; which indeed he had almo≈øt effected, togeather with the deliuery of many more Chri≈øtians that were in the ≈øame Pri≈øon; but becau≈øe he could not breake open the pri≈øon doores without great noy≈øe, nor bring to pa≈ø≈øe what he had determined, with that ≈øecrecy he de≈øired, his plot was ≈øoone di≈øcouered, and all the Pri≈øoners brought backe againe into pri≈øon.

When the Emperour heard of this, he tooke the matter ≈øo heynou≈øly, and was ≈øo inraged again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, a≈øwell in regard of the new comming of
tho≈øe Religious men into his Kingdome, to preach the Chri≈øtian fayth, as al≈øo, becau≈øe they had broken his Maie≈øties pri≈øon; that without delay, he commaÃÑ ded the Gouernour of Nanga≈øachi pre≈øeÃÑtly to repayre to Firandum, and there put to death fir≈øt of all Ioachim the Captayne, and afterwards the two Religious men that he brought with him, as al≈øo all the other Marriners, that were Chri≈øtians. Moreouer he commanded, that all other Religious men, whether they were of Europe, or of Iaponia who were impri≈øoned in diuers Cittyes ≈øhould be put to death. And the like puni≈øhment he charged to be inflicted vpon all Widows, and Orphanes, who≈øe Husbands, or Parents had in the former Per≈øecution of late yeares, ≈øuffered death for the fayth of Chri≈øt.

The Gouernour with all ≈øpeed, at the Emperours commaundment, came to Firandum, where calling for the pri≈øoners, he began to examine and aske them many que≈øtions; as, whether they were Chri≈øtians? From whence they came? Of what Nation they were? And when, and where they were baptized? Nor he did forget, now and then to exhort them to renounce their Fayth, promi≈øing them their liues, if they would ≈øo do; & affirming that he had full power and Commi≈ø≈øioÃÑ from the Emperour, for what he promi≈øed.

But to this la≈øt, one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame mo≈øt con≈øtant Reply was made by all; That nothing in the world ≈øhould cau≈øe them deny their fayth, nor breake the promi≈øe they had made to IESVS CHRIST in Bapti≈øme. Vpon which an≈øwere and firme re≈øolution, the
Gouernour pre≈øently pronounced ≈øentence, and condemned the Captayne Ioachim, and the two Religious Fathers Pedro de Zuniga the Augu≈øtine Friar, and Father Lewis de Flores the Dominican, to be burned aliue, & the re≈øt of the Marriners, who were twelue in number, to be beheaded.

Now the≈øe holy Confe≈ø≈øours of IESVS CHRIST hauing receaued this doom, the more to increa≈øe their ioy and a≈ø≈øurance of dying for Chri≈øts ≈øake, demanded of the Gouernour, for what cau≈øe he adiudged them to death? And they receiued this an≈øwere in very plaine tearmes: to wit, that the Religious men mu≈øt dye, becau≈øe they had again≈øt the Emperours decree, entred into Iaponia to preach the law of Chri≈øt; and the re≈øt for that they had brought the ≈øaid Preachers into the Countrey to that end. Which plaine declaration was an exceeding ioy and Iubily of heart vnto them all, when they ≈øaw them≈øelues condemned to death for the fayth, and loue of IESVS CHRIST.

The place appointed for the execution, was out of the Citty of Firandum, where there was a faire and large plot of ground, like vnto an Amphitheater, all inclo≈øed round with woodden rayles. Hither were the holy CoÃÑfe≈ø≈øours brought forth of the Citty, with infinite multitudes of people, and the three foremo≈øt placed ech one at a pillar, or ≈øtake, whereunto they were bound, with great aboundance of fagots, and wood layd round about them. But before the fire was kindled, the other twelue Marriners heads were ≈øtrokeÃÑ off within the fore≈øaid place, before the eyes of the Holy Confe≈ø≈øours, that ≈øtood now ready at the ≈øtake
to be burned.

Heere now the good Captayne Ioachim made knowne the force of Chri≈øtian Eloquence, being not only permitted, but al≈øo commanded by the ≈øayd two Religious Fathers his Companions (who by rea≈øon of the ≈øhort tyme of their abode in Iaponia, had not yet learned the language of that countrey) to profe≈ø≈øe the fayth of Chri≈øt in the name of all the re≈øt. Of whome, ≈øuch as did both ≈øee and heare him, do affirme, that he ≈øeemed rather to ≈øpeake like an Apo≈øtle, then an ordinary Preacher, much le≈ø≈øe a poore Marriner; ≈øuch was the feruour, ≈øuch the courage wherewith he preached IESVS CHRIST, in the very midde≈øt of the fyre and ≈ømoke. And by how much more the barbarous Gentils endeauoured a≈øwell by often interrupting him, as by threats, to make him hold his peace; ≈øo much the more did he cry out, and ≈øay, that it was meet he ≈øhould rather obey God then Man. Neyther, can I be terrified (≈øayd he) by your threatninges: for what more cruell, or more grieuous torment can you deui≈øe, then that which I now indure in burning heere aliue? And this he ≈øaid out of the midde≈øt of the burning fire, as if it had bene out of a flaming pulpit, with an admirable feruour of ≈øpirit, being indeed inflamed with the loue of IESVS CHRIST. Nor did he leaue darting out ≈øuch fiery words, vntill him≈øelfe, togeather with his two mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Companions, with wonderfull con≈øtancy ended their liues, and that in ≈øo quiet a manner, as if they had been altogeather immoueable, and wrapt in heauenly contemplation.

This fir≈øt Pageant was repre≈øented vpon the
one and twentith day of Augu≈øt, in the yeare of our Lord 1622. in pre≈øence of an infinite number of Chri≈øtians, who by continuall acclamations and crying out, and calling vpon God to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, endeauoured by all meanes po≈ø≈øible to encourage the holy Martyrs to ≈øuffer death patiently, for the loue of IESVS CHRIST.

The Executioners, as ≈øoone as they perceyued that the Martyrs were dead, went, and expo≈øed the heads of tho≈øe which they had fir≈øt ≈øtroken of, vpon a very high Table, to the greater feare, and terrour of all that ≈øhould behold them. But the bodyes, a≈øwell of tho≈øe that were beheaded, as of tho≈øe that were burned, they layd them all vpon a heape togeather, within the place of execution, well guarded round about with railes of wood, as al≈øo with ≈øouldiers, vntill further order were giueÃÑ what ≈øhould be done with them.

The concour≈øe of the people that came thither both night and day to wor≈øhip tho≈øe Holy Reliques, was wonderfull; notwith≈øtanding the many and grieuous blowes, yea and wounds which they receyued of the ≈øouldiers who were commanded there to watch, that no Chri≈øtian ≈øhould take away any of the ≈øame. But yet all they could do, was not inough to preuaile again≈øt the good de≈øires of the Chri≈øtians, but that ≈øome of the more principall ≈øort, what by their owne Indu≈øtry, and what by bribing of the ≈øouldiers, with pious deceyt ≈øtole away ≈øome of the bodyes. Among≈øt which they had a particular care to take away the whole body of Father Pedro de Zuniga, with intention to conuay it fir≈øt to the Citty of Manila, & froÃÑ thence
to ≈øend it into Spaine, where the Honour of ≈øo worthy a death, and the ornaments of ≈øo glorious a Triumph, due not only to the excellency of his Vertue and Piety, but al≈øo to the Nobility of his bloud and birth (his Father being Marque≈ø≈øe of Manrique, & ≈øometymes Viceroy of Hi≈øpaniola, or new Spaine) are expected to be celebrated with all due Reuerence and Solemnity.

The Gouernour of Nanga≈øachi, after he had be≈øtowed the crowne of Martyrdome vpon the≈øe victorious Champions, ≈øent his Officers to Omura to fetch tho≈øe other Chri≈øtians, of whome we made mention before, who lay there in pri≈øon, de≈øiring and longing for nothing ≈øo much as to ≈øee that happy houre, wherin they might come to ≈øhed their bloud for the loue of IESVS Chri≈øt.

Behold now heere, I be≈øeech you (Gentle Spectators) behold heere a conflict, nay rather an admirable Combate, and ≈øuch a Combate as the like was neuer ≈øeene before in all Iaponia. Fiue and fifty valiant Champions of IESVS Chri≈øt, vpon one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame day, obteined the victorious Palme of martyrdome, in manner as followeth.

Of the≈øe mo≈øt happy Warryours of Chri≈øt, fiue & twenty were taken out of pri≈øon at Omura, wherin, though ≈øome longer then others, yet all in generall, as young ≈øouldiers they had bene trayned vp in this priuate Fencing-Schoole, with ≈øo hard, and mi≈øerable a v≈øage, as barbarous Heathens are accu≈øtomed to entertaine ≈øuch gue≈øts withall. For, there was made vnder the ground, a mo≈øt horrible and filthy Caue, ≈øcarce large inough for twelue ordinary matt-beds of
bulru≈øhes, to lye one by another. Heere ≈øometimes thirty pri≈øoners, ≈øometimes more, three and three to a matte of eight palmes long, and three in breadth, were con≈øtrained to lodge both night and day, without hauing ≈øo much as one foote of roome more to ≈øtir vp and downe in: & which is more (and of it ≈øelf alone had bene inough to di≈øpatch them all in ≈øhort tyme) in the very ≈øame roome, they were to giue place vnto the nece≈ø≈øity of nature. And as for their dyet, the daily pittance allowed them, was a little di≈øh of blacke Ryce, with a few broyled Pilchards, or as it chanced now and then a ≈øuppe of broth, wherein Radi≈øh leaues had bene boyled.

In the meane time, while≈øt the Officers were taking the≈øe couragious ChaÃÑpions out of the fore≈øaid mi≈øerable dungeon, to be conueyed to the place of execution, the Gouernour called for thirty men & women al≈øo out of the pri≈øon of Nanga≈øachi, whome he determined to put to death togeather, with tho≈øe that were to come from Omura. And when he had giuen ≈øentence of death again≈øt them, commanding that the ≈øame ≈øhould be put in execution the next day, he ≈øent them backe againe vnto pri≈øon: who albeit they went chayned all togeather, like malefactours, worthy to dye for mo≈øt notorious crymes; yet they departed froÃÑ the Iudgment ≈øeat with great Ioy and Iubily of heart, euery one holding vp a Crucifix, or other Cro≈ø≈øe in his hand, as high as he could, in ≈øigne of Tryumph.

The troupe of couragious Women marched fir≈øt; among≈øt whome one more eminent, as Captayne, went before the re≈øt, with a banner of Chri≈øt IESVS
crucifyed di≈øplayed in her hands. After her followed all the re≈øt in maÃÑner of proce≈ø≈øion, ≈øounding forth the pray≈øes of Almighty God, with all honour, and magnificence, and contempt of the Idols with all ≈øcorne and reproach: wherof many of the woman lifted vp in their armes towards Heauen, their little ≈øucking Chri≈øtian Babes, as Sacrifices ready to be offred vnto God together with them≈øelues.

After the women followed the vndaunted band of meÃÑ, putting likewi≈øe theÃÑ≈øelues in ≈øuch order of proce≈ø≈øioÃÑ, that affoarded a mo≈øt worthy & plea≈øaÃÑt ≈øhew vnto the eyes of God, & to all the Chri≈øtians that beheld the ≈øame; who not contented with the only beholding therof, but inflamed with an holy emulation of their hapines, went al≈øo in great nuÃÑbers accoÃÑpanying theÃÑ, & following their ≈øteps with great reuereÃÑce & deuotion.

Not long after this, entred into the Citty the fore≈øaid Pri≈øoners that were ≈øent for from Omura, in number fiue and twenty, among≈øt whome one and twenty were Religious men of diuers Orders: Whom when the Chri≈øtians of Nanga≈øachi beheld, what flocking made they (thinke you) to come to ≈øee, and to ≈øalute them? Who is able to recount with what teares and ≈øighes euery one now entertained his gho≈øtly Father, by whome he had bene baptized, and regenerated in Chri≈øt IESVS? Who can expre≈ø≈øe with what weeping and lamentation they deplored their owne mo≈øt lamentable ca≈øe, that the≈øe their ≈øpirituall Fathers, Tutours, and Mai≈øters, ≈øhould now be depriued of life, by who≈øe meanes the life of grace had not only bene ≈øo long nouri≈øhed and con≈øerued, but euen
fir≈øt of all infu≈øed into their ≈øoules? In the meane tyme, the ioyfull Fathers cea≈øed not to comfort their afflicted children, bidding them be of good comfort; & encouraging them to put their tru≈øt in the Fatherly protection of Almighty God; a≈ø≈øuring them that his Infinite Goodnes would neuer let them want other Fathers and Mai≈øters to nouri≈øh, and increa≈øe their good de≈øires. And ≈øo finally exhorting, & animating them to per≈øeuere con≈øtantly in the ≈øincere and true fayth of IESVS Chri≈øt, euen vntill death, they tooke their la≈øt farewells.

Being now come vnto the place of execution, the Officers a≈ø≈øigned euery one a pillar or ≈øtake, wherat he was to be burned; which euery one of the holy Prie≈øts, before they were bound vnto them, falling downe vpon his knees, with great reuerence imbraced, and ≈øaluted with a thou≈øand ki≈ø≈øes: The like al≈øo did the lay Religious Brothers, being moued therunto by the pious example of the Prie≈øts. The ≈øight wherof was a cau≈øe of great admiration to the Beholders, and ≈øtirred vp in the harts of many ≈øo great feeling of deuotion, that they could not refraine from teares.

In this meane tyme, while≈øt tho≈øe thirty pri≈øoners, which (as before we recounted) had bene ≈øent backe with their ≈øentence of death to the pri≈øon, in the ≈øame Citty, were coming towards the ≈øame place of execution; the officers were bu≈øied in binding to their ≈øeuerall pillars the fiue and twenty before named, all whome they bound but very loo≈øely in order following.

Vnto the foure fir≈øt pillars were bound foure Men,
condemned for no other crime, but only becau≈øe they had ≈øometimes entertained and lodged in their hou≈øes with great charity ≈øome of the ≈øayd Religious Fathers. Next vnto the≈øe ≈øtood the one and twenty Religious men, ≈øome of Europe, and the re≈øt of Iaponia. The fir≈øt place among≈øt the≈øe, was allotted to the Reuerend Father Charles Spinola, an Italian Prie≈øt of the Society of IESVS, borne in Genua, and de≈øcended of the renowed Bloud and Family of the Spinola's, greatly reuerenced and accounted of among≈øt all men, by rea≈øon of his Birth, but much more in regard of his excellent Vertue, his rare parts, and ≈øingular endowmeÃÑts both of mind and body; as al≈øo for his exce≈ø≈øiue and continuall labours & paines, employed in cultiuating the vineyard of Chri≈øt IESVS in Iaponia, ≈øo far from his Natiue Country, which he, and all the re≈øt of tho≈øe who were of Europe, had for≈øakeÃÑ for the loue of God, to gaine ≈øoules in India.

After Father Spinola, followed the ReuereÃÑd Fa. Angelus Ferrerius of the order of S. Dominicke; Fa. Io≈øeph de S. Iacintho of the ≈øame Order; Fa. Iacinthus, al≈øo of the ≈øame. Then followed Father Seba≈øtian Quimura of the Society of IESVS, a Cittizen of Firandum borne in Iaponia, who had liued there thirty yeares in the Society of IESVS, of which he had bene Prie≈øt for the ≈øpace of twenty; being him≈øelf the fir≈øt Iaponian that euer tooke vpoÃÑ him the holy Order of Prie≈øthood, wherin he ≈øhewed him≈øelfe a mo≈øt worthy labourer in the vineyard of his Country, a maÃÑ endowed with ≈øingular Vertues, and an excellent Preacher in the Iaponian language.

Then followed the Reuerend Father Peter de Auila
of the order of S. Francis; Father Richard de S. Anna of the ≈øame Order; Father Alfon≈øus de Mena of the order of S. Dominicke; Father Francis de Morales of the ≈øame.

They that were not Prie≈øts, were placed in this order: Vincentius, a Religious Brother of the order of Saint Francis borne in Europe: Anthony Fugia a Iaponian, of the Society of IESVS: Gon≈øaluus Fu≈øay of the ≈øame Society and Countrey: Petrus Zampo of the ≈øame both religion and Countrey: Michael Iaponen≈øis of the ≈øame Order. After the≈øe againe followed foure other of the order of S. Dominicke: And la≈øt of all were brought three of the Society of IESVS borne in Iaponia, to wit Thomas Aca≈øgin, Ludouicus Cauarato, who were likewi≈øe bound to their pillars, and Iohn Chacoco, who alone among≈øt tho≈øe fiue and twenty that were condemned to the fire, for want of a pillar whereat to be burned, was beheaded pre≈øently; and fir≈øt of all obtayned the crowne of Martyrdome by the ≈øword.

So as to reckon them ouer againe there were of ≈øecular men Foure, that were coÃÑdemned for receiuing of the Religious Fathers into their hou≈øes, Nine religious men of the order of S. Dominicke, Three of Saint Francis, and Nine of the Society of IESVS, all which being put together, do make the full number of fiue and twenty Crowned-Martyrs.
